question_text: What is a key difference between SSD and HDD failure patterns when data recovery is needed?
answer_options: SSDs always fail completely while HDDs can be partially recovered
HDDs are more reliable than SSDs in all failure scenarios
Failed SSDs may still be readable but not writable, while HDDs typically have mechanical failures
SSDs can be repaired easily while HDDs require professional services
correct_answer: Failed SSDs may still be readable but not writable, while HDDs typically have mechanical failures
explanation: When SSDs fail, you often can't write to them but may still be able to read existing data. HDDs typically fail due to mechanical issues (clicking, grinding) that affect both reading and writing. Both types can result in data corruption or complete inaccessibility.
